title: Cold Process Soapmaking - Complete Beginner's Guide
author: Soapmaking Forum Community / @Prysm
overview: Comprehensive guide to cold process soapmaking including saponification chemistry, safety, equipment, recipes, and techniques

what_is_soap.chemistry: Acid (fatty acids from oils) + Base (lye/sodium hydroxide) = Salt (soap)
what_is_soap.reaction: Saponification - converts oils/fats + lye dissolved in water → soap
what_is_soap.lye_truth: Cannot make soap without lye, BUT properly made soap has NO lye remaining
what_is_soap.glycerin: Commercial soaps remove glycerin to increase shelf life and sell separately - homemade soap retains it

vessels.oil_melting: HDPE #2 or PP #5 plastic, or stainless steel
vessels.lye_mixing: HDPE #2 or PP #5 plastic - NOT glass or Pyrex
vessels.warning: Do NOT use aluminum - reacts with lye

equipment_needed.utensils: Stainless steel or silicone spoons - no wooden (degrades over time)

molds.commercial: Silicone molds usually don't need lining
diy: Cardboard boxes lined with freezer paper

equipment_needed.immersion_blender: Highly recommended - saves massive time vs hand stirring

scale.metric: To tenth of gram - preferred for precision
scale.note: All ingredients measured by WEIGHT, not volume

lye_handling.rule_1: Always add LYE to WATER, never water to lye
lye_handling.mnemonic: Add lye to water, just like you oughter
lye_handling.danger: Water to lye will volcano and be dangerous
lye_handling.temperature: Gets HOT fast - always use cold water/liquid
lye_handling.ventilation: Mix in well-ventilated area, avoid breathing fumes
lye_handling.ratio: Generally 2:1 water to lye, or 2.5:1 for extra safety

safety_rules.protection: Wear goggles and gloves throughout entire process
safety_rules.lye_source: Hardware stores with drain cleaners - must be 100% sodium hydroxide, no other ingredients

oil_properties.coconut: Cleansing, great bubbles - too much can be drying
oil_properties.olive: Conditioning - too much makes soft, slimy soap
oil_properties.lard: Stable lather, conditioning, gentle, makes soap hard

basic_recipe.vegan_substitute: Palm oil instead of lard - recalculate lye!
basic_recipe.superfat_explained: Excess oil ensures all lye is used up + conditions skin

step_1.critical: ALWAYS calculate - each oil needs different lye amount

step_2.action: Weigh lye, weigh water, add lye to water
step_2.tip: Use taller vessel than you think you need

step_3.action: Weigh oils, melt hard oils first, add liquid oils

step_4.action: When both are 120°F or less, add lye water slowly to oils
step_4.blending: Use immersion blender in bursts - keep under surface

step_5.trace_definition: When spoon leaves visible line/trail in batter

step_6.action: Pour into mold, cover with towel
step_6.gel_phase: May see clear area in middle - normal process

step_7.action: Unmold when firm like cheddar cheese (~24 hours)
step_7.cut: If too hard = crumbles, too soft = can't unmold

step_8.action: Cure 4-6 weeks on rack in dry place
step_8.result: Becomes milder and sudsier with curing

against_glass.reason_1: Lye can erode glass over time - tiny glass bits in soap

for_glass.new_pyrex: Regular glass - more prone to breaking
for_glass.tip: Place hot glass on wood cutting board, never cold surface
for_glass.amazon: Borosilicate glass measuring cups now available for 'commercial use'

pyrex_controversy.consensus: Plastic recommended for beginners, experienced soapers may use glass

colorants.tip: Add to melted oils before lye to prevent lumps
colorants.disperse: Mix with small amount of oil first

fragrances.warning: Anything with alcohol (perfume) will cause soap to seize
fragrances.always: Check manufacturer's directions and usage rates

community_debate.against_sharing: Some argue lye can hide in cracks, leach into food

for_sharing.lye_facts: Not poisonous - used in bagels, pretzels, olives
for_sharing.after_drying: Raw lye becomes harmless sodium bicarbonate (soda ash)

troubleshooting.lye_heavy_soap: Old 'grandma's soap' that 'takes hide off' - measure carefully
troubleshooting.soft_soap: Too much olive oil, not enough hard oils
troubleshooting.seizing: Fragrance with alcohol, or accelerating fragrance

quiz_questions.a: Chemical reaction between fatty acids (oils) and a base (lye) that creates soap - a salt of fatty acid
quiz_questions.explanation: No lye remains in properly made soap

quiz_questions.q: What is the critical rule for mixing lye and water?
quiz_questions.a: Always add LYE to WATER, never water to lye - 'Add lye to water, just like you oughter'
When moving spoon through batter leaves visible line/trail behind
quiz_questions.explanation: Indicates emulsification complete, ready to pour into mold

quiz_questions.q: Why do homemade soaps need to cure 4-6 weeks?
quiz_questions.a: Becomes milder and sudsier - saponification continues and excess water evaporates
quiz_questions.explanation: Cold process soap isn't fully reacted when poured

quiz_questions.q: What is superfat and why use it?
quiz_questions.a: Excess oil (typically 5%) ensures all lye is used up and provides skin conditioning

achievement_unlocks: Lye Master: Know all safety rules
Process Expert: Execute all steps correctly
